title: TS Eliot's other woman: ‘He loves me – but not in the way usual to men less gifted…’
text:
This week, TS Eliot’s trove of letters to an early love will finally be unsealed. What secrets will they hold?

"I am very dependent upon women,” TS Eliot told his Harvard friend and fellow poet, Conrad Aiken, in 1914. His life was shaped by four women who became part of his work. Vivienne Haigh-Wood, his first wife, Mary Trevelyan, a companion, and Valerie Fletcher, his secretary at Faber & Faber, who became his second wife, are all well known, but there was another woman who came first, named Emily Hale.

For decades, this was a relationship “under wraps”, as Eliot’s Faber colleague, Peter du Sautoy, put it. In the course of their correspondence, from the late Twenties until 1957, Eliot wrote...
description: This week, TS Eliot’s trove of letters to an early love will finally be unsealed.
